title.narrative: HIGH IMPACT INTERVENTIONS

description.narrative: By 2019, the Government of Angola has the Community Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) National Strategic Plan, and local governments implement Community Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) sustainably, as a result of UNICEF's technical assistance, which contributes to Environmental Sustainability, Hygiene, Sanitation, Wash In Schools And Ecd Centres, Wash â€“ General, Water, Water Supply. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Evaluations, Research And Data, Harnessing Power Of Business And Markets, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2019, the most vulnerable boys, girls and families will have access to appropriate water and sanitation facilities and live in open defecation free communities.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2019, the Government of Angola has the CLTS National Strategic Plan, and local governments implement CLTS sustainably, as aresult of UNICEF's technical assistance

description.narrative: Along ACO CPD 2015-2019 192 villages are certified with Open Defecation Free (ODF) status out of 427. The first commune ODF in Angola has been declared in 2019 (200 villages and more than 54,000 people ending open defecation) and officially celebrated at the end of November with the participation of the Ministry of Environment (MINAMB), the provincial government of Bie, the municipal government of Nharea, and the participant communities and their traditional leaders. This 2019 alone 22 villages ODF and 41 news ones waiting to be certified, with a total of 22,859 people living in ODF communities. | Status:Met | As-of Date:17/01/2020
